\(\def \E {\mb {E}}\) \(\def \P {\mb {P}}\) \(\def \R {\mb {R}}\) \(\def \C {\mb {C}}\) \(\def \N {\mb {N}}\) \(\def \Q {\mb {Q}}\) \(\def \Z {\mb {Z}}\) \(\def \B {\mb {B}}\) \(\def \~{\sim }\) \(\def \-{\,;\,}\) \(\def \qed {$\blacksquare $}\) \(\def \1{\unicode {x1D7D9}}\) \(\def \cadlag {c\`{a}dl\`{a}g}\) \(\def \p {\partial }\) \(\def \l {\left }\) \(\def \r {\right }\) \(\def \Om {\Omega }\) \(\def \om {\omega }\)

4.5 Exercises

  • 4.1 Use Theorem 4.1.1 to prove part 6 of Theorem 4.2.1.

  • 4.2 Write down ‘probabilistic’ versions of the monotone convergence theorem, Fatou’s lemma and the dominated convergence theorem. That is, use random variables in place of measurable functions and expectation in place of the integral.

  • 4.3 Let \(X\) be a random variable and \(a \in \R \). Prove that

    \[ \E [\max \{X, a\}] \geq \max \{\E [X], a\}.\]

    Hint: Write \(\E [\max \{X, a\}]\) as an integral.

  • 4.4 Let \(X\) be a real-valued random variable defined on a probability space \((\Omega , {\cal F}, \P )\). Use the result of Exercise 3.5 to derive the probabilistic version of Chebychev’s inequality:

    \[ \P \l [|X - \mu | \geq c\r ] \leq \ds \frac {\var (X)}{c^{2}},\]

    where \(\var (X)\) and \(\E [X] = \mu \) are both assumed to be finite.

  • 4.5 Let \(U\) be a random variable such that \(\P [U=-1]=\P [U=1]=\frac 12\) and let \(V\) be a random variable such that \(\P [V=0]=\P [V=1]=\frac 12\), independent of \(U\). Let \(X=UV\) and \(Y=U(1-V)\). Show that \(\E [XY]=\E [X]\E [Y]\) but that \(X\) and \(Y\) are not independent.

  • 4.6

    • (a) Let \((A_n)\) be a sequence of independent events. Show that

      \(\seteqnumber{0}{4.}{0}\)

      \begin{equation} \label {eq:inf_indep} \P \l [\bigcap _{n\in \N } A_n\r ]=\prod _{n=1}^\infty \P [A_n]. \end{equation}

    • (b) Recall that we define independence of a sequence of events \((A_{n})\) in terms of finite subsequences (e.g. as in Section 4.4). An ‘obvious’ alternative definition might to be use (4.1) instead. Why is this not a sensible idea?

  • 4.7

    • (a) Let \(A\) and \(B\) be independent events. Show that their complements \(A^c\) and \(B^c\) are also independent.

    • (b) Let \(X\) and \(Y\) be independent random variables and \(f,g:\R \rightarrow \R \) be Borel measurable. Deduce that \(f(X)\) and \(g(Y)\) are also independent.

  • 4.8 Let \(\eps >0\). Let \((E_n)\) be a sequence of independent events such that \(\P [E_n]\geq \eps \) for all \(n\in \N \). Show that \(\P [\cup _{n\in \N } E_n]=1\).

  • 4.9

    • (a) Let \(X\) be a random variable that takes values in \(\N \cup \{0\}\). Explain why \(X = \sum _{i=1}^{\infty }{\1}_{\{X \geq i\}}\) and hence show that

      \[\E [X] = \sum _{i=1}^{\infty }\P [X \geq i].\]

    • (b) Let \(Y\) be a non-negative random variable taking values in \(\R \). Deduce that

      \[ \sum _{k=1}^{\infty }\P [Y \geq k] \;\leq \; \E [Y] \;\leq \; 1 + \sum _{k=1}^{\infty }\P [Y \geq k].\]

  • 4.10 Let \(X\) be a random variable. Show that there are at most countably many \(x\in \R \) such that \(\P [X=x]>0\).

    Hint: What happens to \(F_X(x)\) at \(x\) such that \(\P [X=x]>0\)?

  • 4.11

    • (a) Suppose that \(X\) and \(Y\) are random variables and both \(X^{2}\) and \(Y^{2}\) are integrable. Prove the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality:

      \[ |\E [XY]| \leq \l (\E [X^{2}]^{\frac {1}{2}}\r )\l (\E [Y^{2}]^{\frac {1}{2}}\r ).\]

      Hint: Consider \(g(t) = \E [(X + tY)^{2}]\) as a quadratic function of \(t \in \R \).

    • (b) Deduce that if \(X^{2}\) is integrable then so is \(X\), and in fact \(|\E [X]|^{2} \leq \E [X^{2}]\).

    • (c) Let \(X\) be any random variable with a finite mean \(\E [X]=\mu \). Show that \(\E [X^{2}] < \infty \) if and only if \(\var (X) < \infty \).

  • 4.12 A random variable is said to have an exponential moment if \(\E [e^{a|X|}] < \infty \) for some \(a > 0\).

    • (a) Let \(X\) be a non-negative random variable and \(a > 0\). Show that \(\E [e^{-aX} ] \leq 1\).

    • (b) Show that \(X \sim N(0,1)\) has exponential moments for all \(a > 0\).

    • (c) Let \(X\) be a random variable with an exponential moment. Show that \(\E [|X|^{n}] < \infty \) for all \(\nN \).

  • 4.13 Let \(X\) be a real-valued random variable with law \(p_{X}\) defined on a probability space \((\Omega , {\cal F}, \P )\). Show that for all bounded measurable functions \(f:\R \rightarrow \R \),

    \[ \int _{\Omega }f(X(\omega ))\,d\P (\omega ) = \int _{\R }f(x)\,dp_{X}(x).\]

    What can you say about these integrals when \(f\) is non-negative but not necessarily bounded?

    Hint: Begin with \(f\) an indicator function, then extend to simple, bounded non-negative and general bounded measurable functions.

Challenge questions

  • 4.14 Let \(\eps >0\). Let \((\Omega ,\mc {F},\P )\) be a probability space and suppose that \((E_n)_{n\in \N }\) is a sequence of independent events, with \(\P [E_n]\in (\eps ,1-\eps )\) for all \(n\in \N \). Show that \(\P [\omega ]=0\) for all \(\omega \in \Omega \) and, hence, deduce that \(\Omega \) is uncountable.

Copyright Nic Freeman, Sheffield University, last updated March 23, 2023

\(\newcommand{\footnotename}{footnote}\) \(\def \LWRfootnote {1}\) \(\newcommand {\footnote }[2][\LWRfootnote ]{{}^{\mathrm {#1}}}\) \(\newcommand {\footnotemark }[1][\LWRfootnote ]{{}^{\mathrm )}\) \(\newcommand {\F }{{\cal F}}\) \(\newcommand {\ds }{\displaystyle }\) \(\newcommand {\st }{\stackrel {d}{=}}\) \(\newcommand {\uc }{\stackrel {uc}{\rightarrow }}\) \(\newcommand {\la }{\langle }\) \(\newcommand {\ra }{\rangle }\) \(\newcommand {\li }{\liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\ls }{\limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\limn }{\lim _{n \rightarrow \(\def \E {\mb {E}}\) \(\def \P {\mb {P}}\) \(\def \R {\mb {R}}\) \(\def \C {\mb {C}}\) \(\def \N {\mb {N}}\) \(\def \Q {\mb {Q}}\) \(\def \Z {\mb {Z}}\) \(\def \B {\mb {B}}\) \(\def \~{\sim }\) \(\def \-{\,;\,}\) \(\def \qed {$\blacksquare $}\) \(\def \1{\unicode {x1D7D9}}\) \(\def \cadlag {c\`{a}dl\`{a}g}\) \(\def \p {\partial }\) \(\def \l {\left }\) \(\def \r {\right }\) \(\def \Om {\Omega }\) \(\def \om {\omega }\)

Chapter 5 Sequences of random variables

In this section we think about sequences of random variables, and about taking limits of random variables. As with real numbers, sequences and limits are our main tool for justifying the use of approximations. Approximations allow us to better understand complicated models, by giving us a way to replace complicated random objects with simpler ones (whilst still maintaining some degree of accuracy). As such, this theory underpins much of stochastic modelling.

5.1 The Borel-Cantelli lemmas

The Borel-Cantelli lemmas are a tool for understanding the tail behaviour of a sequence \((E_n)\) of events. The key definitions are

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{0}\)

\begin{align*} \{E_n\text { i.o.}\} &= \{E_n, \mbox { infinitely often}\} &= \bigcap _m \bigcup _{n\ge m} E_n &= \{\om : \om \in E_n \mbox { for infinitely many $n$}\} \\ \{E_n\text { e.v.}\} &= \{E_n, \mbox { eventually}\} &= \bigcup _m \bigcap _{n\ge m} E_n &= \{\om : \om \in E_n \mbox { for all sufficiently large $n$}\}. \end{align*} The set \(\{E_n\text { i.o.}\}\) is the event that infinitely many of the individual events \(E_n\) occur. The set \(\{E_n\text { e.v.}\}\) is the event that, for some (random) \(N\), all the events \(E_n\) for which \(n\geq N\) occur.

For example, we might take an infinite sequence of coin tosses and choose \(E_n\) to be the event that the \(n^{th}\) toss is a head. Then \(\{E_n\text { i.o.}\}\) is the event that infinitely many heads occur, and \(\{E_n\text { e.v.}\}\) is the event that, after some point, all remaining tosses show heads.

Note that by straightforward set algebra,

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{0}\)

\begin{equation} \label {evio} \Omega \sc \{E_n\text { i.o.}\}=\{\Omega \sc E_n\text { e.v.}\}. \end{equation}

In our coin tossing example, \(\Omega \sc E_n\) is the event that the \(n^{th}\) toss is a tail. So (5.1) says that ‘there are not infinitely many heads’ if and only if ‘eventually, we see only tails’.

The Borel-Cantelli lemmas, respectively, give conditions under which the probability of \(\{E_n\text { i.o.}\}\) is either \(0\) or \(1\).

  • Lemma 5.1.1 (First Borel-Cantelli Lemma) Let \((E_n)_{n\in \N }\) be a sequence of events and suppose \(\sum _{n=1}^\infty \P [E_n]<\infty \). Then \(\P [E_n\text { i.o.}]=0\).

Proof: We have

\[\P \l [\bigcap _N\bigcup _{n\geq N} E_n\r ]= \lim _{N\to \infty } \P \l [\bigcup _{n\geq N} E_N\r ]\leq \lim _{N\to \infty }\sum \limits _{n=N}^\infty \P [E_n]=0,\]

Here, the first step follows by applying Theorem 4.1.1 to the decreasing sequence of events \((B_N)\) where \(B_N=\bigcup _{n\geq N} E_n\). The second stop follows by Lemma 1.7.2 and the fact that limits preserve weak inequalities. The final step follows because \(\sum _{n=1}^\infty \P [E_n]<\infty \).   ∎

For example, suppose that \((X_n)\) are random variables that take the values \(0\) and \(1\), and that \(\P [X_n=1]=\frac {1}{n^2}\) for all \(n\). Then \(\sum _n\P [X_n=1]=\sum _n\frac {1}{n^2}<\infty \) so, by Lemma 5.1.1, \(\P [X_n=1\text { i.o.}]=0\), which by (5.1) means that \(\P [X_n=0\text { e.v.}]=1\). So, almost surely, beyond some (randomly• located) point in our sequence \((X_n)\), we will see only zeros. Note that we did not require the \((X_n)\) to be independent.

  • Lemma 5.1.2 (Second Borel-Cantelli Lemma) Let \((E_n)_{n\in \N }\) be a sequence of independent events and suppose that \(\sum _{n=1}^\infty \P [E_n]=\infty \). Then \(\P [E_n\text { i.o.}]=1\).

Proof: Write \(E^c_n=\Omega \sc E_n\). We will show that \(\P [E^c_n\text { e.v.}]=0\), which by (5.1) implies our stated result. Note that

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{1}\)

\begin{equation} \label {eq:Encleq} \P [E^c_n\text { e.v.}] =\P \l [\bigcup _N\bigcap _{n\geq N} E^c_n\r ] \leq \sum \limits _{N=1}^\infty \P \l [\bigcap _{n\geq N}E^c_n\r ] \end{equation}

by Lemma 1.7.2. Moreover, since the \((E_n)\) are independent, so are the \((E^c_n)\), so

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{2}\)

\begin{equation*} \P \l [\bigcap _{n\geq N}E^c_n\r ]=\prod \limits _{n=N}^\infty \P [E^c_n]=\prod \limits _{n=N}^\infty (1-\P [E_n])\leq \prod \limits _{n=N}^\infty e^{-\P [E_n]}=\exp \l (-\sum \limits _{n=N}^\infty \P [E_n]\r )=0. \end{equation*}

Here, the first step follows by Exercise 4.6. The second step is immediate and the third step uses that \(1-x\leq e^{-x}\) for \(x\in [0,1]\). The fourth step is immediate and the final step holds because \(\sum _n\P [E_n]=\infty \). By (5.2) we thus have \(\P [E^c_n\text { e.v.}]=0\).   ∎

For example, suppose that \((X_n)\) are i.i.d. random variables such that \(\P [X_n=1]=\frac {1}{2}\) and \(\P [X_n=-1]=\frac {1}{2}\). Then \(\sum _n\P [X_n=1]=\infty \) and, by Lemma 5.1.2, \(\P [X_n=1\text { i.o.}]=1\). By symmetry, we have also \(\P \l [X_n=0\text { i.o.}\r ]=1\). So, if we look along our sequence, almost surely we will see infinitely many \(1\)s and infinitely many \(0\)s.

Since both the Borel-Cantelli lemmas come down to summing a series, a useful fact to remember from real analysis is that, for \(p\in \R \),

\[\sum \limits _{n=1}^\infty n^{-p}<\infty \hspace {1pc}\iff \hspace {1pc}p>1.\]

Recall that this fact follows from the integral test for convergence of series.

Copyright Nic Freeman, Sheffield University, last updated March 23, 2023

{#1}}}\) \(\let \LWRorighspace \hspace \) \(\renewcommand {\hspace }{\ifstar \LWRorighspace \LWRorighspace }\) \(\newcommand {\mathnormal }[1]{{#1}}\) \(\newcommand \ensuremath [1]{#1}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRframebox }[2][]{\fbox {#2}} \newcommand {\framebox }[1][]{\LWRframebox } \) \(\newcommand {\setlength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtolength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\setcounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtocounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\arabic }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\number }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\noalign }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\newcommand {\cline }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\directlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\luatexdirectlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\protect }{}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbnumber #1 {}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbquotenumber "#1 {}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorboption }[1][]{}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorbtwooptions }[1][]{\LWRabsorboption }\) \(\def \mathchar {\ifnextchar "\LWRabsorbquotenumber \LWRabsorbnumber }\) \(\def \mathcode {x00C6}}\) \(\def \aa {\unicode {x00E5}}\) \(\def \AA {\unicode {x00C5}}\) \(\def \o {\unicode {x00F8}}\) \(\def \O {\unicode {x00D8}}\) \(\def \l {\unicode {x0142}}\) \(\def \L {\unicode {x0141}}\) \(\def \ss {\unicode {x00DF}}\) \(\def \SS {\unicode {x1E9E}}\) \(\def \dag {\unicode {x2020}}\) \(\def \ddag {\unicode {x2021}}\) \(\def \P {\unicode {x00B6}}\) \(\def \copyright {\unicode {x00A9}}\) \(\def \pounds {\unicode {x00A3}}\) \(\let \LWRref \ref \) \(\renewcommand {\ref }{\ifstar \LWRref \LWRref }\) \( \newcommand {\multicolumn }[3]{#3}\) \(\require {textcomp}\) \(\newcommand {\intertext }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\let \Hat \hat \) \(\let \Check \check \) \(\let \Tilde \tilde \) \(\let \Acute \acute \) \(\let \Grave \grave \) \(\let \Dot \dot \) \(\let \Ddot \ddot \) \(\let \Breve \breve \) \(\let \Bar \bar \) \(\let \Vec \vec \) \(\DeclareMathOperator {\var }{var}\) \(\DeclareMathOperator {\cov }{cov}\) \(\newcommand {\nN }{n \in \mathbb {N}}\) \(\newcommand {\Br }{{\cal B}(\R )}\) \(\newcommand {\F }{{\cal F}}\) \(\newcommand {\ds }{\displaystyle }\) \(\newcommand {\st }{\stackrel {d}{=}}\) \(\newcommand {\uc }{\stackrel {uc}{\rightarrow }}\) \(\newcommand {\la }{\langle }\) \(\newcommand {\ra }{\rangle }\) \(\newcommand {\li }{\liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\ls }{\limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\limn }{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\def \to {\rightarrow }\) \(\def \iff {\Leftrightarrow }\) \(\def \sw {\subseteq }\) \(\def \mc {\mathcal }\) \(\def \mb {\mathbb }\) \(\def \sc {\setminus }\) \(\def \v {\textbf }\) \(\def \-{\,;\,}\) \(\def \qed {$\blacksquare $}\) \(\def \1{\unicode {x1D7D9}}\) \(\def \cadlag {c\`{a}dl\`{a}g}\) \(\def \p {\partial }\) \(\def \l {\left }\) \(\def \r {\right }\) \(\def \Om 5.2 Convergence of Random Variables

Let \((X_{n})\) be a sequence of random variables, all of which are defined on the same probability space \((\Omega , {\cal F}, \P )\). There are various different ways in which we can examine the convergence of this sequence to a random variable \(X\) (which is also defined on \((\Omega , {\cal F}, \P )\). They are called modes of convergence.

When we talk about convergence of real numbers \(a_n\to a\) we only have one mode of convergence, which we might think of as convergence of the value of \(a_n\) to the value of \(a\). Random variables are much more complicated objects; they take many different values with different probabilities. For this reason, there are multiple different modes of convergence of random variables.

We say that \((X_{n})\) converges to \(X\)

  • • in distribution if whenever \(\P [X=x]=0\) we have \(\P [X_n\leq x]\to \P [X\leq x]\).

  • • in probability if given any \(a > 0\), we have \(\P [|X_{n} - X| \geq a] \to 0\) as \(n\to \infty \),

  • • almost surely if \(\P [X_{n}(\omega ) \to X(\omega ),\text { as }n\to \infty ]=1\),

  • • in \(L^p\) if \(\E [|X_{n} - X|^{p}] \to 0\) as \(n\to \infty \).

When \((X_{n})\) converges to \(X\) almost surely we sometimes write \(X_{n} \rightarrow X\) a.s. as \(n \rightarrow \infty \). We may also write the type of convergence above the arrow e.g. \(X_n\stackrel {L^2}{\to }X\) or \(X_n\stackrel {a.s.}{\to }X\).

For \(L^p\) convergence we are usually only interested in the cases \(p=1\) and \(p=2\). The case \(p=2\) is sometimes known as convergence in mean square. For reasons that are outside of the scope of this course, \(L^p\) convergence is only defined for \(p\in [1,\infty )\).

Happily, there are some relationships between these different modes of convergence.

  • Lemma 5.2.1 Let \(X_n,X\) be random variables.

    • 1. If \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to } X\) then \(X_n\stackrel {d}{\to } X\).

    • 2. If \(X_n\stackrel {a.s.}{\to } X\) then \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to } X\).

    • 3. If \(X_n\stackrel {L^p}{\to } X\) then \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to } X\).

    • 4. Let \(1\leq p< q\). If \(X_n\stackrel {L^q}{\to } X\) then \(X_n\stackrel {L^p}{\to } X\).

No other relationships exist in general, other than those implied by the above results.

Proof: The last part follows from the counterexamples in Exercises 5.1-5.3. We’ll give proofs of parts 1-4 here.

Part 1. Let \(x\in \R \) be such that \(\P [X=x]=0\) and let \(\epsilon >0\). We have

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{2}\)

\begin{align} \P [X\leq x] &=\P [X\leq x, |X_n-X|<\epsilon ]+\P [X\leq x, |X_n-X|\geq \epsilon ]\notag \\ &\leq \P [X_n\leq x+\epsilon ]+\P [|X_n-X|\geq \epsilon ].\label {eq:pd1} \end{align} Putting \(x-\epsilon \) in place of \(x\) we obtain

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{3}\)

\begin{align} \P [X\leq x-\epsilon ] &\leq \P [X_n\leq x]+\P [|X_n-X\geq \epsilon ].\label {eq:pd2} \end{align} Combining (5.3) and (5.4) leads to

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{4}\)

\begin{align*} \P [X\leq x-\epsilon ]-\P [|X_n-X|\geq \epsilon ] \;\leq \; \P [X_n\leq x] \;\leq \; \P [X\leq x+\epsilon ]+\P [|X_n-X|\geq \epsilon ]. \end{align*} By Remark 4.2.2 and the fact that \(\P [X=x]=0\) we have that \(y\mapsto \P [X\leq y]\) is continuous at \(y=x\). Hence, letting \(\epsilon \to 0\), both \(\P [X\leq x+\epsilon ]\) and \(\P [X\leq x-\epsilon ]\) converge to \(\P [X\leq x]\). Since limits preserve weak inequalities this gives

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{4}\)

\begin{align*} \P [X\leq x]-\P [|X_n-X|\geq \epsilon ] \;\leq \; \P [X_n\leq x] \;\leq \; \P [X\leq x]+\P [|X_n-X|\geq \epsilon ]. \end{align*} Letting \(n\to \infty \) and using that \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to } X\), the sandwich rule gives \(\P [X_n\leq x]\to \P [X\leq x]\).

Part 2. Let \(\epsilon > 0\) be arbitrary and let \(A_{n} = \bigcup _{m = n}^{\infty }\{|X_{m} - X| \geq \epsilon \}\). Then \((A_{n})\) is a decreasing sequence of events. Let \(A = \bigcap _{n=1}^{\infty }A_{n}\). If \(\omega \in A\) then \(X_{n}(\omega )\) cannot converge to \(X(\omega )\) as \(n \rightarrow \infty \) and so \(\P [A] = 0\), because \(X_n\to X\) almost surely. By Theorem 4.1.1 part (2), \(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }\P [A_{n}] = \P [A] = 0\). But then by monotonicity,

\[ \P [|X_{n} - X| \geq \epsilon ] \leq \P [A_{n}] \rightarrow 0~\mbox {as}~n \rightarrow \infty .\]

Part 4. \((\star )\) We’ll prove part 4 next, because it will be helpful in part 3 below. This part is non-examinable because we need an inequality that is (just) outside of our own syllabus. It is true that

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{4}\)

\begin{equation} \label {eq:jensen_p} \E [|X|]^p\leq \E [|X|^p] \end{equation}

for all \(p\geq 1\) and all random variables \(X\). For general \(p\), this is a special case of a result known as Jensen’s inequality, which we don’t cover in this course. However, the \(p=2\) case is a consequence of the Cauchy-Schwartz inequality, which appears in these notes as Exercise 4.11. We have already seen the \(p=1\) case in equation (3.7) and Exercise 3.8.

Putting \(|X_n-X|^p\) into (5.5), and then putting \(q/p\geq 1\) in place of \(p\), we obtain that \(\E [|X_n-X|^p]^{q/p}\leq (\E [|X_n-X|^{p(q/p)}]).\) Thus \(\E [|X_n-X|^p]\leq (\E [|X_n-X|^{q}])^{p/q}\). The result follows.

Part 3. Thanks to part 4, it suffices to prove that \(L^1\) convergence implies convergence in probability. From Markov’s inequality (Lemma 3.3.2) for any \(a > 0\) we have

\[\P [|X_{n} - X| \geq a] \leq \ds \frac {\E [|X_{n} - X|]}{a}.\]

If \(X_n\stackrel {L^1}{\to }X\) then the right hand side tends to zero as \(n\to \infty \), hence so does the left.   ∎

  • Remark 5.2.2 The following diagram records which modes of convergence imply which other modes of convergence.

    In all other cases (i.e. that are not automatically implied by the above), convergence in one mode does not imply convergence in another.

Recall that for real numbers, if \(a_n\to a\) and \(a_n\to b\) then \(a=b\), which is known as uniqueness of limits. For random variables, the situation is a little more complicated: if \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to } X\) and \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to } Y\) then \(X=Y\) almost surely. By Lemma 5.2.1, this result also applies to \(\stackrel {L^p}{\to }\) and \(\stackrel {a.s.}{\to }\). However, if we have only \(X_n\stackrel {d}{\to } X\) and \(X_n\stackrel {d}{\to } Y\) then we can only conclude that \(X\) and \(Y\) have the same distribution, that is \(\P [X\leq x]=\P [Y\leq x]\) for all \(x\). Proving these facts is Exercise 5.7.

Establishing convergence in distribution, probability and \(L^p\) usually comes down to calculating (or estimating) the important quantities involved: \(\P [X\leq x]\), \(\P [|X_n-X|\leq a]\) and \(\E [|X_n-X|^p]\), and then thinking about their limits as \(n\to \infty \). There are several examples of this type within the exercises. Almost sure convergence is harder to work with, but here we can often use the Borel-Cantelli lemmas.

  • Example 5.2.3 Let \((X_n)\) be a sequence of i.i.d. random variables, each with the uniform distribution on \([0,1]\). Then \(\P [X_n\leq \frac 13]=\P [X_n\geq \frac 23]=\frac 13\), so (using independence) by two applications of the second Borel-Cantelli lemma we have \(\P [X_n\leq \frac 13\text { i.o.}]=\P [X_n\geq \frac 23\text { i.o.}]=1\). Hence, with probability \(1\), the sequence \(X_n\) will oscillate infinitely often between \([0,\frac 13]\) and \([\frac 23,1]\), in which case it cannot converge. Thus \((X_n)\) does not converge almost surely (to any limit) in this case.

    Alternatively, consider a sequence \((Y_n)\) with \(\P [Y_n=1]=\frac {1}{n^2}\) and \(\P [Y_n=0]=1-\frac {1}{n^2}\). Since \(\sum \frac 1{n^2}<\infty \), the first Borel-Cantelli lemma tells us that \(\P [Y_n=1\text { i.o.}]=0\). Hence \(\P [Y_n=0\text { e.v.}]=1\), which implies that \(\P [Y_n\to 0]=1\), or in other words that \(Y_n\stackrel {a.s.}{\to }0\).

  • Lemma 5.2.4 If \(X_{n} \rightarrow X\) in probability as \(n \rightarrow \infty \) then there is a subsequence of \((X_{n})\) that converges to \(X\) almost surely.

Proof: If \((X_{n})\) converges in probability to \(X\), for all \(c > 0\), given any \(\epsilon > 0\), there exists \(N(c) \in \mathbb {N}\) so that for all \(n \geq N(c)\), \(\P [|X_{n} - X| > c] < \epsilon .\)

In order to find our subsequence:

– First choose, \(c = 1\) and \(\epsilon = 1/2\), then for \(n \geq N(1)\), \(\P [|X_{n} - X| > 1] < 1/2.\)

– Next choose \(c = 1/2\) and \(\epsilon = 1/4\), then for \(n \geq N(2)\), \(\P [|X_{n} - X| > 1/2] < 1/4.\)

– In general, choose \(c = 1/r\) and \(\epsilon = 1/2^{r}\), then for \(n \geq N(r)\), \(\P [|X_{n} - X| > 1/r] < 1/2^{r}.\)

Set \(k_{r} = \max \{N(1),N(2),\ldots ,N(r),r\}\) for \(r \in \mathbb {N}\). to obtain a subsequence \((X_{k_{r}})\) so that for all \(r \in \mathbb {N}\),

\[ \P [|X_{k_{r}} - X| > 1/r] < 1/2^{r}.\]

Since \(\sum \frac {1}{2^{r}} < \infty \), by the first Borel-Cantelli lemma (Lemma 5.1.1) we have

\[\P [|X_{k_{r}} - X| > 1/r\;\;i.o.] = 0,\]

and so

\[\P [|X_{k_{r}} - X| \leq 1/r\;\;e.v.] = 1.\]

Hence, almost surely, there exists some \(R\in \N \) such that for all \(r\geq R\) we have \(|X_{{k_{r}}} - X| < 1/r\), which implies that \(|X_{{k_{r}}} - X|\to 0\). Hence \(X_{{k_r}}\to X\) almost surely.   ∎

  • Remark 5.2.5 A subtle point is that the subsequence of \((X_n)\) constructed by Lemma 5.2.4 is a deterministic subsequence, in the sense that \(r\mapsto k_r\) is a deterministic function. Of course, \(X_{k_r}\) is a random variable for each \(r\).

Copyright Nic Freeman, Sheffield University, last updated March 23, 2023

Probability with Measure

\(\newcommand{\footnotename}{footnote}\) \(\def \LWRfootnote {1}\) \(\newcommand {\footnote }[2][\LWRfootnote ]{{}^{\mathrm {#1}}}\) \(\newcommand {\footnotemark }[1][\LWRfootnote ]{{}^{\mathrm {#1}}}\) \(\let \LWRorighspace \hspace \) \(\renewcommand {\hspace }{\ifstar \LWRorighspace \LWRorighspace }\) \(\newcommand {\mathnormal }[1]{{#1}}\) \(\newcommand \ensuremath [1]{#1}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRframebox }[2][]{\fbox {#2}} \newcommand {\framebox }[1][]{\LWRframebox } \) \(\newcommand {\setlength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtolength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\setcounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtocounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\arabic }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\number }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\noalign }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\newcommand {\cline }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\directlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\luatexdirectlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\protect }{}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbnumber #1 {}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbquotenumber "#1 {}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorboption }[1][]{}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorbtwooptions }[1][]{\LWRabsorboption }\) \(\def \mathchar {\ifnextchar "\LWRabsorbquotenumber \LWRabsorbnumber }\) \(\def \mathcode #1={\mathchar }\) \(\let \delcode \mathcode \) \(\let \delimiter \mathchar \) \(\def \oe {\unicode {x0153}}\) \(\def \OE {\unicode {x0152}}\) \(\def \ae {\unicode {x00E6}}\) \(\def \AE {\unicode {x00C6}}\) \(\def \aa {\unicode {x00E5}}\) \(\def \AA {\unicode {x00C5}}\) \(\def \o {\unicode {x00F8}}\) \(\def \O {\unicode {x00D8}}\) \(\def \l {\unicode {x0142}}\) \(\def \L {\unicode {x0141}}\) \(\def \ss {\unicode {x00DF}}\) \(\def \SS {\unicode {x1E9E}}\) \(\def \dag {\unicode {x2020}}\) \(\def \ddag {\unicode {x2021}}\) \(\def \P {\unicode {x00B6}}\) \(\def \copyright {\unicode {x00A9}}\) \(\def \pounds {\unicode {x00A3}}\) \(\let \LWRref \ref \) \(\renewcommand {\ref }{\ifstar \LWRref \LWRref }\) \( \newcommand {\multicolumn }[3]{#3}\) \(\require {textcomp}\) \(\newcommand {\intertext }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\let \Hat \hat \) \(\let \Check \check \) \(\let \Tilde \tilde \) \(\let \Acute \acute \) \(\let \Grave \grave \) \(\let \Dot \dot \) \(\let \Ddot \ddot \) \(\let \Breve \breve \) \(\let \Bar \bar \) \(\let \Vec \vec \) \(\DeclareMathOperator {\var }{var}\) \(\DeclareMathOperator {\cov }{cov}\) \(\newcommand {\nN }{n \in \mathbb {N}}\) \(\newcommand {\Br }{{\cal B}(\R )}\) \(\newcommand {\F }{{\cal F}}\) \(\newcommand {\ds }{\displaystyle }\) \(\newcommand {\st }{\stackrel {d}{=}}\) \(\newcommand {\uc }{\stackrel {uc}{\rightarrow }}\) \(\newcommand {\la }{\langle }\) \(\newcommand {\ra }{\rangle }\) \(\newcommand {\li }{\liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\ls }{\limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\limn }{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\def \to {\rightarrow }\) \(\def \iff {\Leftrightarrow }\) \(\def \sw {\subseteq }\) \(\def \mc {\mathcal }\) \(\def \mb {\mathbb }\) \(\def \sc {\setminus }\) \(\def \v {\textbf }\) \(\def \E {\mb {E}}\) \(\def \P {\mb {P}}\) \(\def \R {\mb {R}}\) \(\def \C {\mb {C}}\) \(\def \N {\mb {N}}\) \(\def \Q {\mb {Q}}\) \(\def \Z {\mb {Z}}\) \(\def \B {\mb {B}}\) \(\def \~{\sim }\) \(\def \-{\,;\,}\) \(\def \qed {$\blacksquare $}\) \(\def \1{\unicode {x1D7D9}}\) \(\def \cadlag {c\`{a}dl\`{a}g}\) \(\def \p {\partial }\) \(\def \l {\left }\) \(\def \r {\right }\) \(\def \Om {\Omega }\) \(\def \om {\omega }\)

5.3 Laws of Large Numbers

Let \((X_{n})\) be a sequence of random variables all defined on the same probability space, that have the following properties,

  • • they are independent;

  • • they are identically distributed i.e. \(p_{X_{n}} = p_{X_{m}}\) for all \(n \neq m\). In other words, for all \(A \in {\cal B}(\R )\),

    \[ \P [X_{1} \in A] = \P [X_{2} \in A] = \cdots = \P [X_{n} \in A] = \cdots \]

Such a sequence is said to be ‘i.i.d.’. Sequences of this type are very important in modelling (consider the steps of a random walk) and also statistics (consider a sequence of idealised experiments carried out under identical conditions).

We are interested in the empirical mean

\[ \overline {X_{n}} = \frac {1}{n}(X_{1} + X_{2} + \cdots + X_{n}),\]

which in statistics is often known as the sample mean. If \(X_{n}\) is integrable for some (and hence all) \(\nN \), with \(\mu =\E [X_n]\), then by linearity \(\overline {X_{n}}\) is integrable and \(\E [\overline {X_{n}}] = \mu \). It is extremely important to learn about the asymptotic behaviour of \(\overline {X_{n}}\) as \(n \rightarrow \infty \). Two key results are the weak law of large numbers (WLLN) and the strong law of large numbers (SLLN). The strong law implies the weak law, but it is much trickier to prove. We will include a full proof of the weak law and a partial proof of the strong law.

  • Theorem 5.3.1 (WLLN) Let \((X_{n})\) be a sequence of integrable i.i.d. random variables with \(\E (X_{n}) = \mu \) for all \(\nN \). Suppose also that \(\E [X_{n}^{2}] < \infty \) for all \(\nN \). Then \(\overline {X_{n}} \rightarrow \mu \) in probability as \(n \rightarrow \infty \).

Proof: Let \(\sigma ^{2} = \var (X_{n})\) for all \(\nN \). Since the \((X_n)\) are independent, it follows that \(\var (\overline {X_n})=\frac {\sigma ^2}{n}\). Then by Chebychev’s inequality, for all \(a > 0\),

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{5}\)

\begin{align*} \P \l [|\overline {X_{n}} - \mu | > a\r ] \leq \frac {\var (\overline {X_{n}})}{a^{2}} = \frac {\sigma ^{2}}{na^{2}} \end{align*} which tends to zero as \(n\to \infty \).   ∎

  • Theorem 5.3.2 (SLLN) Let \((X_{n})\) be a sequence of integrable i.i.d. random variables with \(\E (X_{n}) = \mu \) for all \(\nN \). Then \(\overline {X_{n}} \rightarrow \mu \) almost surely as \(n \rightarrow \infty \).

The full proof of the SLLN is too long for this course. You can find it in e.g. Rosenthal on pages 47-49. We’ll give the proof in a special case, by making an assumption on the fourth moments of the sequence \((X_{n})\), and then remark on the general case.

  • Assumption 5.3.3 \(\E [(X_{n} - \mu )^{4}] = b < \infty \) for all \(\nN \).

Proof:[Of Theorem 5.3.2 under Assumption 5.3.3.] Without loss of generality we may assume that \(\mu =0\). To see this, instead of \(X_{n}\) we would consider \(Y_{n} = X_{n}- \mu \).

Let \(S_{n} = X_{1} + X_{2} + \cdots + X_{n}\) so that \(S_{n} = n\overline {X_{n}}\) for all \(\nN \). Consider \(\E [S_{n}^{4}]\). It contains many terms of the form \(\E [X_{j}X_{k}X_{l}X_{m}]\) with distinct indices and these all vanish by independence, because \(\E [X_j]=\E [X_k]=\E [X_l]=\E [X_m]=0\). A similar argument disposes of terms of the form \(\E [X_{j}X_{k}^{3}]\) and \(\E [X_{j}X_{k}X_{l}^{2}]\), where \(j,k,l\) are distinct. The only terms with non-vanishing expectation are \(n\) terms of the form \(X_{i}^{4}\) and \({n \choose 2}{4 \choose 2} = 3n(n-1)\) terms of the form \(X_{i}^{2}X_{j}^{2}\) with \(i \neq j\). By Theorem 4.4.2, \(X_{i}^{2}\) and \(X_{j}^{2}\) are independent for \(i \neq j\) and so by Theorem 4.4.2

\[ \E [X_{i}^{2}X_{j}^{2}] = \E [X_{i}^{2}]E[X_{j}^{2}] = \var (X_{i}^{2})\var (X_{j}^{2}) = \sigma ^{4}.\]

Putting all this together,

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{5}\)

\begin{align*} \E [S_{n}^{4}] & = \sum _{i=1}^{n}\E [X_{i}^{4}] + \sum _{i \neq j}\E [X_{i}^{2}X_{j}^{2}]\\ & = nb + 3n(n-1)\sigma ^{4} \leq K n^{2}, \end{align*} where \(K = b + 3\sigma ^{4}\). For all \(a > 0\), by Markov’s inequality (Lemma 3.3.1)

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{5}\)

\begin{align*} \P [|\overline {X_{n}}| > a] = \P [S_{n}^{4} > a^{4}n^{4}] \leq \frac {\E [S_{n}^{4}]}{a^{4}n^{4}} \leq \ds \frac {Kn^{2}}{a^{4}n^{4}} = \ds \frac {K}{a^{4}n^{2}}. \end{align*} Recall that \(\sum _{n=1}^{\infty }\frac {1}{n^{2}} < \infty \). Hence, by the first Borel-Cantelli lemma, \(\P [|\overline {X_{n}}| > a\;\text {i.o.}] = 0\) and so \(\P [|\overline {X_{n}}| \leq a\;\text {e.v.}] = 1\). It follows that \(\overline {X_{n}} \rightarrow 0\) a.s. as required.   ∎

  • Remark 5.3.4 (\(\star \)) The proof, in the general case without Assumption 4.1, uses a truncation argument, based on \(Y_{n} = X_{n}{\1}_{\{X_{n} \leq n\}}\). Then \(Y_{n} \leq n\) for all \(n\) and so \(\E [Y_{n}^{k}] \leq n^{k}\) for all \(k\). If \(X_{n} \geq 0\) for all \(n\), \(\E [Y_{n}] \rightarrow \mu \) by monotone convergence. Roughly speaking the argument is to prove a SLLN for the \(\overline {Y_{n}}\)s, and then transfer this to the \(\overline {X_{n}}\)s. It requires much more work.

If \(\E (X_{n}^{2}) < \infty \) then (by Problem 4.11) \(\var (X_{n}) = \sigma ^{2} < \infty \) for some (and hence all) \(\nN \). It follows by elementary properties of the variance that \(\var (\overline {X_{n}}) = \frac {\sigma ^{2}}{n}\). This is known as the empirical variance or sample variance. The Central Limit Theorem investigates this quantity, as we will see in Section 5.5.

Copyright Nic Freeman, Sheffield University, last updated March 23, 2023

\(\newcommand {\addtocounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\arabic }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\number }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\noalign }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\newcommand {\cline }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand 5.4 Characteristic Functions and Weak Convergence (\(\star \))

In this section, we introduce two tools that we will need to prove the central limit theorem. They rely on Lebesgue integration in \(\C \), which we introduced in Remark 3.6.4 and studied in exercises 3.17-3.21. Note that this section and the next are marked with a (\(\star \)), meaning that they are off-syllabus but are included for interest.

5.4.1 Characteristic Functions (\(\star \))

Let \((S, \Sigma , m)\) be a measure space and \(f:S \rightarrow \C \) be a complex-valued function. Then we can write \(f = f_{1} + i f_{2}\) where \(f_{1}\) and \(f_{2}\) are real-valued functions. We say that \(f\) is measurable/integrable if both \(f_{1}\) and \(f_{2}\) are. Define \(|f|(x) = |f(x)| = \sqrt {f_{1}(x)^{2} + f_{2}(x)^{2}}\) for each \(x \in S\). It is not difficult to see that \(|f|\) is measurable, using e.g. Problem 2.4. In Problem 5.11 we show that \(f\) is integrable if and only if \(|f|\) is integrable. With this definition, the Dominated Convergence Theorem continues to hold for sequences of measurable functions from \(S\) to \(\C \). We’ll omit a proof of this fact; it consists of applying our existing version of the theorem to real and imaginary parts.

  • Definition 5.4.1 Let \(X\) be a random variable defined on a probability space \((\Omega , {\cal F}, \P )\). The characteristic function \(\phi _{X}:\R \rightarrow \C \) of \(X\) and is defined, for each \(u \in \R \), by

    \(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{5}\)

    \begin{equation} \label {eq:char_func} \phi _{X}(u) = \E [e^{iuX}] = \int _{\R }e^{iuy}p_{X}(dy). \end{equation}

Note that \(y \rightarrow e^{iuy}\) is measurable since \(e^{iuy} = \cos (uy) + i\sin (uy)\) and integrability holds since \(|e^{iuy}| \leq 1\) for all \(y \in \R \) and in fact we have \(|\phi _{X}(u)| \leq 1\) for all \(u \in \R \). Characteristic functions are unique to random variables in the following sense.

  • Theorem 5.4.2 If \(X\) and \(Y\) are two random variables for which \(\phi _{X}(u)=\phi _{Y}(u)\) for all \(u \in \R \) then \(p_{X} = p_{Y}\).

  • Example 5.4.3 Suppose that \(X \sim N(\mu , \sigma ^{2})\), that is \(X\) has a normal distribution (sometimes known as a Gaussian) with mean \(\mu \) and variance \(\sigma ^{2}\). In Problem 5.12 you can show for yourself that in this case \(\phi _{X}(u) = \exp \l (i\mu u - \frac {1}{2}\sigma ^{2}u^{2}\r )\) for all \(u \in \R \).

Equation 5.6 states that the characteristic function of \(X\) is the Fourier transform of the law \(p_{X}\) of the random variable \(X\). In elementary probability theory courses we often meet the Laplace transform \(\E [e^{uX}]\) of \(X\), which is called the moment generating function of \(X\). The moment generating function has the disadvantage that it only exists when \(|u|\) is small enough, because the function \(y \mapsto e^{uy}\) may not be integrable. How small \(|u|\) is required to be depends on \(X\), but unfortunately there are random variables for which \(\E [e^{uX}]\) is undefined for all \(u\neq 0\). In such cases the moment generating function is useless. The characteristic function has the important advantage that it is always defined for all \(u\in \R \).

Here is one useful property of characteristic functions, which is another instance of the ‘independence means multiply’ philosophy that we developed in Section 4.4.

  • Theorem 5.4.4 If \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent random variables then for all \(u \in \R \),

    \[ \phi _{X+Y}(u) = \phi _{X}(u)\phi _{Y}(u).\]

Proof: We have \(\phi _{X+Y}(u) = \E \big [e^{iu(X+Y)}\big ] = \E \l [e^{iuX}e^{iuY}\r ] = \E \l [e^{iuX}\r ]\E \l [e^{iuY}\r ] = \phi _{X}(u)\phi _{Y}(u)\), where the key step follows by Theorem 4.4.2.   ∎

5.4.2 Weak Convergence (\(\star \))

A sequence \((\mu _{n})\) of measures on \(\R \) is said to converge weakly to a measure \(\mu \) if

\[ \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty } \int _{\R } f(x) \,d\mu _{n}(x) = \int _{\R } f(x) \,d\mu (x) \]

for all bounded continuous functions \(f\) defined on \(\R \). This is a generalization of the convergence in law that we defined in Section 5.2, and is also equivalent to pointwise convergence of characteristic functions. The following theorem makes the connections precise. We won’t give a proof in this course.

  • Theorem 5.4.5 Let \(X_n,X\) be random variables with laws \(p_{X_n}\) and \(p_X\) (respectively), and characteristic functions \(\phi _n\) and \(\phi \). The following statements are equivalent:

    • 1. \(X_n\stackrel {d}{\to } X\);

    • 2. for all \(u\in \R \) we have \(\phi _n(u)\to \phi (u)\);

    • 3. for all bounded measurable functions \(f:\R \to \R \) we have

      \[\int _\R f(x)\,dp_{X_n}(x)\to \int _\R f(x)\,dp_X(x).\]

We’ve seen that there are several different modes of convergence for random variables. The same is true for measures, although we won’t make a list of them in this course. For further reading on this topic you might like to investigate ‘convergence in total variation’ and ‘vague convergence’.

5.4.3 An inequality concerning characteristic functions \((\star )\)

We will now develop an important inequality that we will need to prove the central limit theorem. Let \(x \in \R \) and let \(R_{n}(x)\) be the remainder term of the series expansion at \(n \in \mathbb {N} \cup \{0\}\) in \(e^{ix}\), i.e.

\[ R_{n}(x) = e^{ix} - \ds \sum _{k=0}^{n}\frac {(ix)^{k}}{k!}.\]

Note that \(R_{0}(x) = e^{ix} - 1 = \left \{\begin {array}{c c}\int _{0}^{x}ie^{iy}dy &~\mbox {if}~x > 0\\ -\int _{x}^{0}ie^{iy}dy &~\mbox {if}~x < 0 \end {array}\right .\). From the last two identities, we have \(|R_{0}(x)| \leq \min \{|x|, 2\}.\) Then you should check that \(R_{n}(x) = \left \{\begin {array}{c c} \int _{0}^{x}iR_{n-1}(y)dy&~\mbox {if}~x > 0\\ -\int _{x}^{0}iR_{n-1}(y)dy &~\mbox {if}~x < 0 \end {array}\right . \). Finally using induction, we can deduce the useful inequality:

\[ |R_{n}(x)| \leq \min \left \{\frac {2|x|^{n}}{n!}, \frac {|x|^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}\right \}.\]

Now let \(X\) be a random variable with characteristic function \(\phi _{X}\) for which \(\E (|X|^{n}) < \infty \) for some given \(\nN \). Then integrating the last inequality yields for all \(y \in \R \)

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{6}\)

\begin{equation} \label {remain} \left |\phi _{X}(y) - \sum _{k=0}^{n}\frac {(iy)^{k}\E (X^{k})}{k!}\right | \leq \E \left [\min \left \{\frac {2|yX|^{n}}{n!}, \frac {|yX|^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}\right \}\right ]. \end{equation}

Equation (5.7) allows us to approximate a characteristic function with a polynomial, and quantify how large the error involved is. In some regions of \(y\in \R \) the error may be small, but in others it may be very large.

When we prove the CLT we will want to apply equation (5.7) in the case \(n=2\) to a random variable that has \(\E (X) = 0\). In this case, writing \(\E (X^{2}) = \sigma ^{2}\) we deduce that for all \(u \in \R \)

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{7}\)

\begin{equation} \label {remain2} \left |\phi _{X}(y) - 1 + \frac {1}{2}\sigma ^{2}y^{2}\right | \leq \theta (y), \end{equation}

where \(\theta (y) = \ds y^{2}\E \left [\min \left \{|X|^{2}, |y|\frac {|X|^{3}}{6}\right \}\right ].\) Note that

\[\min \left \{|X|^{2}, |y|\frac {|X|^{3}}{6}\right \} \leq |X|^{2}\]

which is integrable by assumption. Also we have

\[\lim _{y \rightarrow 0}\min \left \{|X|^{2}, |y|\frac {|X|^{3}}{6}\right \} = 0,\]

and so by the dominated convergence theorem we can deduce that

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{8}\)

\begin{equation} \label {remain3} \ds \lim _{y \rightarrow 0}\frac {\theta (y)}{y^{2}} = 0. \end{equation}

Copyright Nic Freeman, Sheffield University, last updated March 23, 2023

Probability with Measure

\(\newcommand{\footnotename}{footnote}\) \(\def \LWRfootnote {1}\) \(\newcommand {\footnote }[2][\LWRfootnote ]{{}^{\mathrm {#1}}}\) \(\newcommand {\footnotemark }[1][\LWRfootnote ]{{}^{\mathrm {#1}}}\) \(\let \LWRorighspace \hspace \) \(\renewcommand {\hspace }{\ifstar \LWRorighspace \LWRorighspace }\) \(\newcommand {\mathnormal }[1]{{#1}}\) \(\newcommand \ensuremath [1]{#1}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRframebox }[2][]{\fbox {#2}} \newcommand {\framebox }[1][]{\LWRframebox } \) \(\newcommand {\setlength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtolength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\setcounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtocounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\arabic }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\number }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\noalign }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\newcommand {\cline }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\directlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\luatexdirectlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\protect }{}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbnumber #1 {}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbquotenumber "#1 {}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorboption }[1][]{}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorbtwooptions }[1][]{\LWRabsorboption }\) \(\def \mathchar {\ifnextchar "\LWRabsorbquotenumber \LWRabsorbnumber }\) \(\def \mathcode #1={\mathchar }\) \(\let \delcode \mathcode \) \(\let \delimiter \mathchar \) \(\def \oe {\unicode {x0153}}\) \(\def \OE {\unicode {x0152}}\) \(\def \ae {\unicode {x00E6}}\) \(\def \AE {\unicode {x00C6}}\) \(\def \aa {\unicode {x00E5}}\) \(\def \AA {\unicode {x00C5}}\) \(\def \o {\unicode {x00F8}}\) \(\def \O {\unicode {x00D8}}\) \(\def \l {\unicode {x0142}}\) \(\def \L {\unicode {x0141}}\) \(\def \ss {\unicode {x00DF}}\) \(\def \SS {\unicode {x1E9E}}\) \(\def \dag {\unicode {x2020}}\) \(\def \ddag {\unicode {x2021}}\) \(\def \P {\unicode {x00B6}}\) \(\def \copyright {\unicode {x00A9}}\) \(\def \pounds {\unicode {x00A3}}\) \(\let \LWRref \ref \) \(\renewcommand {\ref }{\ifstar \LWRref \LWRref }\) \( \newcommand {\multicolumn }[3]{#3}\) \(\require {textcomp}\) \(\newcommand {\intertext }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\let \Hat \hat \) \(\let \Check \check \) \(\let \Tilde \tilde \) \(\let \Acute \acute \) \(\let \Grave \grave \) \(\let \Dot \dot \) \(\let \Ddot \ddot \) \(\let \Breve \breve \) \(\let \Bar \bar \) \(\let \Vec \vec \) \(\DeclareMathOperator {\var }{var}\) \(\DeclareMathOperator {\cov }{cov}\) \(\newcommand {\nN }{n \in \mathbb {N}}\) \(\newcommand {\Br }{{\cal B}(\R )}\) \(\newcommand {\F }{{\cal F}}\) \(\newcommand {\ds }{\displaystyle }\) \(\newcommand {\st }{\stackrel {d}{=}}\) \(\newcommand {\uc }{\stackrel {uc}{\rightarrow }}\) \(\newcommand {\la }{\langle }\) \(\newcommand {\ra }{\rangle }\) \(\newcommand {\li }{\liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\ls }{\limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\limn }{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\def \to {\rightarrow }\) \(\def \iff {\Leftrightarrow }\) \(\def \sw {\subseteq }\) \(\def \mc {\mathcal }\) \(\def \mb {\mathbb }\) \(\def \sc {\setminus }\) \(\def \v {\textbf }\) \(\def \E {\mb {E}}\) \(\def \P {\mb {P}}\) \(\def \R {\mb {R}}\) \(\def \C {\mb {C}}\) \(\def \N {\mb {N}}\) \(\def \Q {\mb {Q}}\) \(\def \Z {\mb {Z}}\) \(\def \B {\mb {B}}\) \(\def \~{\sim }\) \(\def \-{\,;\,}\) \(\def \qed {$\blacksquare $}\) \(\def \1{\unicode {x1D7D9}}\) \(\def \cadlag {c\`{a}dl\`{a}g}\) \(\def \p {\partial }\) \(\def \l {\left }\) \(\def \r {\right }\) \(\def \Om {\Omega }\) \(\def \om {\omega }\)

5.5 The Central Limit Theorem (\(\star \))

Let \((X_{n})\) be a sequence of i.i.d. random variables having finite mean \(\mu \) and finite variance \(\sigma ^{2}\). We have already met the SLLN which tells us that \(\overline {X_{n}}\) converges to \(\mu \) a.s. as \(n \rightarrow \infty \). Note that the standard deviation (i.e. the square root of the variance) of \(\overline {X_{n}}\) is \(\sigma /\sqrt {n}\) which also converges to zero as \(n \rightarrow \infty \). Now consider the sequence \((Y_{n})\) of standardised random variables defined by

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{9}\)

\begin{equation} \label {stand} Y_{n} = \ds \frac {\overline {X_{n}} - \mu }{\sigma /\sqrt {n}} = \ds \frac {S_{n} - n\mu }{\sigma \sqrt {n}} \end{equation}

Then \(\E (Y_{n}) = 0\) and Var\((Y_{n}) = 1\) for all \(\nN \).

Its difficult to underestimate the importance of the next result. It shows that the normal distribution has a universal character as the attractor of the sequence \((Y_{n})\). From a modelling point of view, it tells us that as you combine together many i.i.d. different observations then they aggregate to give a normal distribution. This is of vital importance in applied probability and statistics. Note however that if we drop our standing assumption that all the \(X_{n}\)’s have a finite variance, then this would no longer be true.

  • Theorem 5.5.1 (Central Limit Theorem) Let \((X_{n})\) be a sequence of i.i.d. random variables each having finite mean \(\mu \) and finite variance \(\sigma ^{2}\). Then the corresponding sequence \((Y_{n})\) of standardised random variables converges in distribution to the standard normal \(Z \sim N(0,1)\), i.e. for all \(a \in \R \)

    \[ \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }\P (Y_{n} \leq a) = \frac {1}{\sqrt {2\pi }}\int _{-\infty }^{a}e^{-\frac {1}{2}y^{2}}dy.\]

Before we give the proof, we state a known fact from elementary analysis. We know that for all \(y \in \R \),

\[ \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }\left (1 + \frac {y}{n}\right )^{n} = e^{y}.\]

Now for all \(y \in \R \), let \((\alpha _{n}(y))\) be a sequence of real (or complex) numbers for which \(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }\alpha _{n}(y) = 0\). Then we also have that for all \(y \in \R \)

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{10}\)

\begin{equation} \label {anal} \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }\left (1 + \frac {y + \alpha _{n}(y)}{n}\right )^{n} = e^{y} \end{equation}

You may want to try your hand at proving this rigorously.

Proof: For convenience we assume that \(\mu = 0\) and \(\sigma = 1\). Indeed if it isn’t we can just replace \(X_{n}\) everywhere by \((X_{n} - \mu )/\sigma \). Let \(\psi \) be the common characteristic function of the \(X_{n}\)s so that in particular \(\psi (u) = \E (e^{iuX_{1}})\) for all \(u \in \R \). Let \(\phi _{n}\) be the characteristic function of \(Y_{n}\) for each \(\nN \). Then for all \(u \in \R \), using Theorem 5.4.4 we find that

\[\begin {aligned} \phi _{n}(u) & = \E (e^{iuS_{n}/\sqrt {n}})\\ & = \E \left (e^{iu(\frac {1}{\sqrt {n}}(X_{1} + X_{2} + \cdots + X_{n})}\right )\\ & = \psi (u/\sqrt {n})^{n}\\ & = \E \left (e^{i\frac {u}{\sqrt {n}}X_{1}}\right )^{n}\\ & = \left (1 + \frac {iu}{\sqrt {n}}\E (X_{1}) - \frac {u^{2}}{2n}\E (X_{1}^{2}) + \frac {\theta _{n}(u)}{n}\right )^{n},\end {aligned}\]

where by (5.8) and the same argument we used to derive (5.9),

\[|\theta _{n}(u)| \leq \ds u^{2}\E \left [\min \left \{|X_{1}|^{2}, \frac {|u|.|X_{1}|^{3}}{6\sqrt {n}}\right \}\right ] \rightarrow 0\]

as \(n \rightarrow \infty \), for all \(u \in \R \). Lastly, we use (5.11) to find that

\[\phi _{n}(u) = \left (1 - \frac {\frac {u^{2}}{2} - \theta _{n}(u)}{n}\right )^{n}\\ \rightarrow e^{-\frac {1}{2}u^{2}}~\mbox {as}~n \rightarrow \infty .\]

The result then follows by Theorem 5.4.5.   ∎

5.5.1 Further discussion (\(\star \))

The CLT may be extensively generalised. We mention just a few such results here. If the i.i.d. sequence \((X_{n})\) is such that \(\mu = 0\) and \(\E (|X_{n}|^{3}) = \rho ^{3} < \infty \), the Berry-Esseen theorem gives a useful bound for the difference between the cdf of the normalised sum and the cdf \(\Phi \) of the standard normal. To be precise we have that for all \(x \in \R , \nN \):

\[ \left |\P \left (\frac {S_{n}}{\sigma \sqrt {n}} \leq x\right ) - \Phi (x)\right | \leq C\frac {\rho }{\sqrt {n}\sigma ^{3}},\]

where \(C > 0\).

We can also relax the requirement that the sequence \((X_{n})\) be i.i.d.. Consider the triangular array \((X_{nk}, k=1,\ldots ,n, \nN )\) of random variables which we may list as follows:

\(\begin {array}{c c c c c } X_{11} & ~ & ~ & ~ & ~\\ X_{21} & X_{22} & ~ & ~ & ~\\ X_{31} & X_{32} & X_{33} & ~ & ~\\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & ~ & ~ \\ X_{n1} & X_{n2} & X_{n3} & \ldots & X_{nn}\\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots \end {array}\)

We assume that each row comprises independent random variables. Assume further that \(\E (X_{nk}) = 0\) and \(\sigma _{nk}^{2} = \E (X_{nk}^{2}) < \infty \) for all \(k,n\). Define the row sums \(S_{n} = X_{n1} + X_{n2} + \cdots + X_{nn}\) for all \(\nN \) and define \(\tau _{n} = \var (S_{n}) = \sum _{k=1}^{n}\sigma _{nk}^{2}\). Lindeburgh’s central limit theorem states that if we have the asymptotic tail condition

\[ \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }\sum _{k=1}^{n}\frac {1}{\tau _{n}^{2}}\int _{|X_{nk}| \geq \epsilon \tau _{n}}X_{nk}^{2}(\omega )d\P (\omega ) = 0,\]

for all \(\epsilon > 0\) then \(\frac {S_{n}}{\tau _{n}}\) converges in distribution to a standard normal as \(n \rightarrow \infty \).

The highlights of this last chapter have been the proofs of the law of large numbers and central limit theorem. There is a third result that is often grouped together with the other two as one of the key results about sums of i.i.d. random variables. It is called the law of the iterated logarithm and it gives bounds on the fluctuations of \(S_{n}\) for an i.i.d sequence with \(\mu = 0\) and \(\sigma = 1\). The result is quite remarkable. It states that almost surely,

\(\seteqnumber{0}{5.}{11}\)

\begin{equation} \label {lil} \ds \ls \frac {S_{n}}{\sqrt {2n \log \log (n)}} = 1. \end{equation}

This means that (with probability one) if \(c > 1\) then only finitely many of the events \(S_{n} > c\sqrt {2n \log \log (n)}\) occur but if \(c < 1\) then infinitely many of such events occur. This gives a very precise description of the long-term behaviour of \(S_n\).

You should be able to deduce from (5.12) that almost surely

\[\ds \li \frac {S_{n}}{\sqrt {2n \log \log (n)}} = -1.\]

Copyright Nic Freeman, Sheffield University, last updated March 23, 2023

{#1}}}\) \(\let \LWRorighspace \hspace \) \(\renewcommand {\hspace }{\ifstar \LWRorighspace \LWRorighspace }\) \(\newcommand {\mathnormal }[1]{{#1}}\) \(\newcommand \ensuremath [1]{#1}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRframebox }[2][]{\fbox {#2}} \newcommand {\framebox }[1][]{\LWRframebox } \) \(\newcommand {\setlength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtolength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\setcounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtocounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\arabic }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\number }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\noalign }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\newcommand {\cline }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\directlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\luatexdirectlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\protect }{}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbnumber #1 {}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbquotenumber "#1 {}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorboption }[1][]{}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorbtwooptions }[1][]{\LWRabsorboption }\) \(\def \mathchar {\ifnextchar "\LWRabsorbquotenumber \LWRabsorbnumber }\) \(\def \mathcode {x00C6}}\) \(\def \aa {\unicode {x00E5}}\) \(\def \AA {\unicode {x00C5}}\) \(\def \o {\unicode {x00F8}}\) \(\def \O {\unicode {x00D8}}\) \(\def \l {\unicode {x0142}}\) \(\def \L {\unicode {x0141}}\) )}\) \(\newcommand {\F }{{\cal F}}\) \(\newcommand {\ds }{\displaystyle }\) \(\newcommand {\st }{\stackrel {d}{=}}\) \(\newcommand {\uc }{\stackrel {uc}{\rightarrow }}\) \(\newcommand {\la }{\langle 5.6 Exercises

  • 5.1 Let \((X_n)\) be a sequence of i.i.d. random variables such that \(\P [X_n=1]=\P [X_n=0]=\frac 12\). Show that \(X_n\stackrel {d}{\to }X_1\) as \(n\to \infty \), but that this convergence does not hold in probability.

  • 5.2

    • (a) Let \((X_n)\) be a sequence of random variables such that \(\P [X_n=n]=\frac 1{n^2}\) and \(\P [X_n=0]=1-\frac 1{n^2}\). Show that \(X_n\stackrel {a.s}{\to } 0\) and \(X_n\stackrel {L^1}{\to } 0\).

    • (b) Let \((X_n)\) be a sequence of independent random variables such that \(\P [X_n=n]=\frac 1{n}\) and \(\P [X_n=0]=1-\frac 1{n}\). Show that \(X_n\) does not converge to zero almost surely or in \(L^1\).

    • (c) Let \((X_n)\) be a sequence of random variables such that \(\P [X_n=n^2]=\frac 1{n^2}\) and \(\P [X_n=0]=1-\frac 1{n^2}\). Show that \(X_n\stackrel {a.s.}{\to } 0\), and that \(X_n\) does not converge to zero in \(L^1\).

    • (d) Let \((X_n)\) be a sequence of independent random variables such that \(\P [X_n=\sqrt {n}]=\frac 1{n}\) and \(\P [X_n=0]=1-\frac 1{n}\). Show that \(X_n\stackrel {L^1}{\to } 0\), and that \(X_n\) does not converge to almost surely to zero.

    • (e) Deduce that \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to } 0\) in all of the above cases.

  • 5.3 Show that the following sequence \((X_n)\) and candidate limit \(X\) of random variables converges in probability but not almost surely.

    Take \(\Omega = [0,1],{\cal F} = {\cal B}([0,1])\) and \(\P \) to be Lebesgue measure. Take \(X = 0\) and define \(X_{n} = {\1}_{A_{n}}\) where \(A_{1} = [0, 1/2], A_{2} = [1/2, 1], A_{3} = [0, 1/4], A_{4} = [1/4, 1/2], A_{5} = [1/2, 3/4], A_{6} = [3/4, 1], A_{7} = [0, 1/8], A_{8} = [1/8, 1/4]\) etc.

  • 5.4 Let \(k\in \N \). Prove that in a sequence of independent coin tosses, infinitely many runs of \(k\) consecutive heads will occur.

  • 5.5 Let \((\Omega , \mc {F}, \P )\) be a probability space. Let \((A_n)\) be a sequence of events.

    • (a) Show that \(\{ A_{n}\text { e.v.}\} \subseteq \{A_{n}\text { i.o.}\}\).

    • (b) Show that \(\{A_n\text { i.o.}\}^{c} = \{A_n^c\text { e.v.}\}\) and deduce that \(\P [A_n\text { i.o.}] = 1 - \P [A_n^c\text { e.v.}].\)

    • (c) Show that

      \[\P [A_n\text { e.v.}]\;\leq \; \li \P [A_n]\;\leq \; \ls \P [A_{n}] \;\leq \; \P \l [A_{n}\text { i.o.}\r ].\]

  • 5.6 Examine the proof of the weak law of large numbers (Theorem 5.3.1) carefully. Show that the conclusion continues to hold if the requirement that the random variables \((X_{n})\) are i.i.d. is replaced by the weaker condition that they are identically distributed and uncorrelated, that is \(\E [X_{m}X_{n}]= \E [X_{m}]\E [X_{n}]\) whenever \(m \neq n\).

  • 5.7 Let \((X_n)\) be a sequence of random variables, and let \(X\) and \(Y\) be random variables.

    • (a) Show that if \(X_n\stackrel {d}{\to }X\) and \(X_n\stackrel {d}{\to }Y\) then \(X\) and \(Y\) have the same distribution function i.e. \(F_X=F_Y\).

      Hint: If two right-continuous functions are equal almost everywhere, they are equal everywhere.

    • (b) Show that if \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to }X\) and \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to }Y\) then \(X=Y\) almost surely.

  • 5.8

    • (a) Let \(X\) be a random variable and suppose that \(X\geq 0\). Show that

      \[\E [\min (1,X)] \;\leq \; a + \P [X\geq a]\]

      for any \(a\in (0,1]\).

    • (b) Let \((X_n)\) be a sequence of random variables. Suppose that \(X_n\geq 0\) for all \(n\in \N \). Show that

      \[X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to } 0 \quad \text {if and only if}\quad \E [\min (1,X_n)]\to 0\]

      as \(n\to \infty \).

      Hint: Recall Markov’s inequality, \(\P [Y\geq a]\leq \frac {1}{a}\E [Y]\) for \(Y\geq 0\).

Challenge questions

  • 5.9

    • (a) Let \((X_n)\) be a sequence of random variables and let \(c\in \R \) be deterministic. Suppose that \(X_n\stackrel {d}{\to } c\). Show that \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to } c\).

    • (b) Let \((X_n)\) be a sequence of independent random variables and suppose that \(X_n\stackrel {\P }{\to } X\). Show that there exists deterministic \(c\in \R \) such that \(\P [X=c]=1\).

  • 5.10 A sequence \((X_n)\) of random variables is said to convergence completely to the random variable \(X\) if

    \[ \sum _{n} \P [|X_n-X|\geq \epsilon ]<\infty \quad \text { for all }\epsilon >0. \]

    • (a) Show that for sequences of independent random variables, complete convergence is equivalent to almost sure convergence.

    • (b) Find a sequence of (dependent) random variables \((X_n)\) that converges almost surely but not completely.

Additional questions (\(\star \))

These questions are based on the off-syllabus material in Sections 5.4 and 5.5.

  • 5.11 Let \((S, \Sigma )\) be a measurable space and \(f: S \rightarrow \C \) be a (complex-valued) measurable function. Deduce that \(f\) is integrable if and only if \(|f|\) is.

  • 5.12 If \(X\) is a normally distributed random variable with mean \(\mu \) and variance \(\sigma ^{2}\), deduce that its characteristic \(\phi _{X}\) function is given for each \(u \in \R \) by \(\phi _{X}(u) = \exp {\left \{i\mu u - \frac {1}{2}\sigma ^{2}u^{2}\right \}}\).

    Hint: First show that it is sufficient to establish the case \(\mu = 0\) and \(\sigma = 1\) by writing \(Y = \frac {1}{\sigma }(X - \mu )\). Then show that \(y \rightarrow \phi _{Y}(u)\) is differentiable and deduce that \(\phi _{Y}^{\prime }(u) = -u\phi _{Y}(u)\). Now solve the initial value problem using what you know about \(\phi _{Y}(0)\).

  • 5.13 Suppose that \(X\) is a random variable for which \(\E (|X|^{n}) < \infty \) for some \(n\). Explain carefully why

    \[\E (X^{n}) = i^{-n}\left .\frac {d^{n}}{du^{n}}\phi _{X}(u)\right |_{u=0}.\]

  • 5.14 The first central limit theorem (CLT) to be established was due to de Moivre and Laplace. In this case each \(X_{n}\) takes only two values, \(1\) with probability \(p\) and \(0\) with probability \(1-p\) where \(0 < p < 1\) (i.e. the \(X_{n}\)s are i.i.d. Bernoulli random variables.) Write down the form of the CLT in this case (writing the standardised random variable \(Y_{n}\) in terms of \(S_{n} = X_{1} + X_{2} + \cdots + X_{n}\)), and explain its relation to the “binomial approximation to the normal distribution”.

Copyright Nic Freeman, Sheffield University, last updated March 23, 2023

{#1}}}\) \(\let \LWRorighspace \hspace \) \(\renewcommand {\hspace }{\ifstar \LWRorighspace \LWRorighspace }\) \(\newcommand {\mathnormal }[1]{{#1}}\) \(\newcommand \ensuremath [1]{#1}\) \(\newcommand \(\newcommand {\addtocounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\arabic }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\number }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\noalign }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\newcommand {\cline }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorboption }[1][]{}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorbtwooptions }[1][]{\LWRabsorboption }\) \(\def \mathchar {\ifnextchar "\LWRabsorbquotenumber \LWRabsorbnumber }\) \(\def \mathcode {x00C6}}\) \(\def \aa {\unicode {x00E5}}\) \(\def \AA {\unicode {x00C5}}\) \(\def \o {\unicode {x00F8}}\) \(\def \O {\unicode {x00D8}}\) \(\def \l {\unicode {x0142}}\) \(\def \L {\unicode {x0141}}\) \(\def \ss {\unicode {x00DF}}\) \(\def \SS {\unicode {x1E9E}}\) \(\def \dag {\unicode {x2020}}\) \(\def \ddag {\unicode {x2021}}\) \(\def \P {\unicode {x00B6}}\) \(\def \copyright {\unicode {x00A9}}\) \(\def \pounds {\unicode {x00A3}}\) \(\let \LWRref \ref \) \(\renewcommand {\ref }{\ifstar \LWRref \LWRref }\) \( \newcommand {\multicolumn }[3]{#3}\) \(\require {textcomp}\) \(\newcommand {\intertext }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\let \Hat \hat \) \(\let \Check \check \) \(\let \Tilde \tilde \) \(\let \Acute \acute \) \(\let \Grave \grave \) \(\let \Dot \dot \) \(\let \Ddot \ddot \) \(\let \Breve )}\) \(\newcommand {\F }{{\cal F}}\) \(\newcommand {\ds }{\displaystyle }\) \(\newcommand {\st }{\stackrel {d}{=}}\) \(\newcommand {\uc }{\stackrel {uc}{\rightarrow }}\) \(\newcommand {\la }{\langle }\) \(\newcommand {\ra }{\rangle }\) \(\newcommand {\li }{\liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\ls }{\limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\limn }{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\def \to {\rightarrow }\) \(\def \iff {\Leftrightarrow }\) \(\def \sw {\subseteq }\) \(\def \mc {\mathcal }\) \(\def \mb {\mathbb }\) \(\def \sc {\setminus }\) \(\def \v {\textbf }\) \(\def \-{\,;\,}\) \(\def \qed {$\blacksquare $}\) \(\def \1{\unicode {x1D7D9}}\) \(\def \cadlag {c\`{a}dl\`{a}g}\) \(\def \p {\partial }\) \(\def \l {\left }\) \(\def \r {\right }\) \(\def \Om {\Omega }\) \(\def \om {\omega }\)

Chapter 6 Product Measures and Fubini’s Theorem \((\Delta )\)

Note that this chapter is marked with a (\(\Delta \)). This means it is only included in MAS452/6352. It is not included in MAS350. It extends Sections 1.8 and 3.9.1.

In this chapter, we give brief notes which are intended as a summary of additional reading that you are expected to do outside the lectures. They emphasise the main ideas and concepts, but you will need to work carefully through all the relevant proofs. The recommended source is Adams and Guillemin, section 2.5, pp.89-102. This material is examinable. It can be studied straight after Chapter 3.

The aim of this section is to learn more about product measures, and how the theory of Lebesgue integration deals with multiple (double, triple, etc.) integrals. Before delving further into the details of these ideas, we’ll need an additional tool from the theory of \(\sigma \)-fields.

6.1 Dynkin’s \(\pi -\lambda \) Lemma \((\Delta )\)

Let \((S, \Sigma )\) be a measurable space. A collection \(\cal P\) of sets in \(S\) is called a \(\pi \)-system if \(A, B \in {\cal P} \Rightarrow A \cap B \in {\cal P}\) (i.e. \(\cal P\) is closed under intersections).

A collection \(\cal L\) of sets in \(S\) is called a \(\lambda \)-system if

  • (L1) \(S \in {\cal L}\).

  • (L2) If \((E_{n})\) is an increasing sequence of sets in \(\cal L\) (so \(E_{n} \subseteq E_{n+1}\) for all \(\nN \)), then \(\bigcup _{n=1}^{\infty }E_{n} \in {\cal L}\).

  • (L3) If \(E, F \in {\cal L}\) and \(F \subset E\) then \(E - F \in {\cal L}\).

Note that by (L1) and (L3), \(\lambda \)-systems are closed under complements.

  • Proposition 6.1.1 If \(\cal L\) is a \(\lambda \)-system that is also a \(\pi \)-system, then it is a \(\sigma \)-field.

Proof: Since \(\cal L\) is closed under complements and finite intersections, it is closed under finite unions by de Morgan’s laws. To show that \(\cal L\) is a \(\sigma \)-algeba, we need to prove that if \((A_{n})\) is an arbitrary sequence of sets in \(\cal L\), then \(\bigcup _{\nN }A_{n} \in {\cal L}\). This follows by writing \(\bigcup _{\nN }A_{n} = \bigcup _{\nN }B_{n}\) and using (L2), where

\[ B_{1} = A_{1}, B_{2} = B_{1} \cup (A_{2} - B_{1}), B_{3} = B_{2} \cup (A_{3} - B_{2}) \ldots \]

  ∎

Recall that if \(\cal A\) is a collections of sets in \(S\), then \(\sigma ({\cal A})\) is the smallest \(\sigma \)-field which contains \(\cal A\).

  • Lemma 6.1.2 (Dynkin’s \(\pi -\lambda \) Lemma) If \(\cal P\) is a \(\pi \)-system and \(\cal L\) is a \(\lambda \)-system with \({\cal P} \subseteq {\cal L}\), then \(\sigma ({\cal P}) \subseteq {\cal L}\).

Proof:   It suffices to prove that \({\cal L}({\cal P})\), which is the smallest \(\lambda \)-system that contains \(\cal P\), is a \(\sigma \)-field. By Proposition 6.1.1, its enough to prove that \({\cal L}({\cal P})\) is closed under intersections.

Step 1. Fix \(A \in {\cal L}({\cal P})\) and define

\[ {\cal G}_{A} = \{B \subseteq \Omega ; A \cap B \in {\cal L}({\cal P})\}.\]

You should check that \({\cal G}_{A}\) is a \(\lambda \)-system.

Step 2. If \(A, B \in {\cal P}\), then \(A \cap B \in {\cal P} \subseteq {\cal L}({\cal P})\). Hence \(B \in {\cal G}_{A}\). So we’ve shown that \({\cal P} \subseteq {\cal G}_{A}\), when \(A \in {\cal P}\). But in Step 1, we proved that \({\cal G}_{A}\) is a \(\lambda \)-system, and so since \({\cal L}({\cal P})\) is the smallest such, we deduce that \({\cal L}({\cal P}) \subseteq {\cal G}_{A}\). This means in particular that if \(A \in {\cal P}, B \in {\cal L}({\cal P})\), then \(A \cap B \in {\cal L}({\cal P})\).

Step 3. If \(A \in {\cal L}({\cal P})\), then by Step 2 we have \(A \cap B = B \cap A \in {\cal L}({\cal P})\) when \(B \in {\cal P}\). This shows that \({\cal P} \subseteq {\cal G}_{A}\), when \(A \in {\cal L}({\cal P})\). Now using Step 1 again, we find that \({\cal L}({\cal P}) \subseteq {\cal G}_{A}\), and the result then follows.   ∎

  • Corollary 6.1.3 If \(\mc {P}\) is a \(\pi \)-system and \(\mc {F}\) is a \(\sigma \)-field then \(\sigma (\mc {P})\sw \mc {F}\).

This result can be very useful for proving that a function is measurable.

Copyright Nic Freeman, Sheffield University, last updated March 23, 2023

{#1}}}\) \(\let \LWRorighspace \hspace \) \(\renewcommand {\hspace }{\ifstar \LWRorighspace \LWRorighspace }\) \(\newcommand {\mathnormal }[1]{{#1}}\) \(\newcommand \ensuremath [1]{#1}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRframebox }[2][]{\fbox {#2}} \newcommand {\framebox }[1][]{\LWRframebox } \) \(\newcommand {\setlength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtolength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\setcounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtocounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\arabic }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\number }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\noalign }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\newcommand {\cline }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\directlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\luatexdirectlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\protect }{}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbnumber #1 {}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbquotenumber "#1 {}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorboption }[1][]{}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorbtwooptions }[1][]{\LWRabsorboption }\) \(\def \mathchar {\ifnextchar "\LWRabsorbquotenumber \LWRabsorbnumber }\) \(\def \mathcode #1={\mathchar }\) \(\let \delcode \mathcode \) \(\let \delimiter \mathchar \) \(\def \oe {\unicode {x0153}}\) \(\def \OE {\unicode {x0152}}\) \(\def \ae {\unicode {x00E6}}\) \(\def \AE {\unicode {x00C6}}\) \(\def \aa {\unicode {x00E5}}\) \(\def \AA {\unicode {x00C5}}\) \(\def \o {\unicode {x00F8}}\) \(\def \O {\unicode {x00D8}}\) \(\def \l {\unicode {x0142}}\) \(\def \L {\unicode {x0141}}\) \(\def \ss {\unicode {x00DF}}\) \(\def \SS {\unicode {x1E9E}}\) \(\def \dag {\unicode {x2020}}\) \(\def \ddag {\unicode {x2021}}\) \(\def \P {\unicode {x00B6}}\) \(\def \copyright {\unicode {x00A9}}\) \(\def \pounds {\unicode {x00A3}}\) \(\let \LWRref \ref \) \(\renewcommand {\ref }{\ifstar \LWRref \LWRref }\) \( \newcommand {\multicolumn }[3]{#3}\) \(\require {textcomp}\) \(\newcommand {\intertext }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\let \Hat \hat \) \(\let \Check \check \) \(\let \Tilde \tilde \) \(\let \Acute \acute \) \(\let \Grave \grave \) \(\let \Dot \dot \) \(\let \Ddot \ddot \) \(\let \Breve \breve \) \(\let \Bar \bar \) \(\let \Vec \vec \) \(\DeclareMathOperator {\var }{var}\) \(\DeclareMathOperator {\cov }{cov}\) \(\newcommand {\nN }{n \in \mathbb {N}}\) \(\newcommand {\Br }{{\cal B}(\R )}\) \(\newcommand {\F }{{\cal F}}\) \(\newcommand {\ds }{\displaystyle }\) \(\newcommand {\st }{\stackrel {d}{=}}\) \(\newcommand {\uc }{\stackrel {uc}{\rightarrow }}\) \(\newcommand {\la }{\langle }\) \(\newcommand {\ra }{\rangle }\) \(\newcommand {\li }{\liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\ls }{\limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\limn }{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\def \to {\rightarrow }\) \(\def \iff {\Leftrightarrow }\) \(\def \sw {\subseteq }\) \(\def \mc {\mathcal }\) \(\def \mb {\mathbb }\) \(\def \sc {\setminus }\) \(\def \v {\textbf }\) \(\def \E {\mb {E}}\) \(\def \P {\mb {P}}\) \(\def \R {\mb {R}}\) \(\def \C {\mb {C}}\) \(\def \N {\mb {N}}\) \(\def \Q {\mb {Q}}\) \(\def \Z {\mb {Z}}\) \(\def \B {\mb {B}}\) \(\def \~{\sim }\) \(\def \-{\,;\,}\) \(\def \qed {$\blacksquare $}\) \(\def \1{\unicode {x1D7D9}}\) \(\def \cadlag {c\`{a}dl\`{a}g}\) \(\def \p {\partial }\) \(\def \l {\left }\) \(\def \r {\right }\) \(\def \Om {\Omega }\) \(\def \om {\omega }\)

6.2 Product Measure \((\Delta )\)

Let \((S_{1}, \Sigma _{1}, m_{1})\) and \((S_{2}, \Sigma _{2}, m_{2})\) be measure spaces.

The set \(S_{1} \times S_{2}: = \{(s_{1}, s_{2}); s_{1}\in S_{1}, s_{2} \in S_{2}\}\) is the usual Cartesian product of sets. If \(A \subseteq S_{1}, B \subseteq S_{2}\), the subset \(A \times B\) of \(S_{1} \times S_{2}\) is called a product set.

The \(\sigma \)-field \(\Sigma _{1} \otimes \Sigma _{2}\) is defined to be the smallest \(\sigma \)-field of subsets of \(S_{1} \times S_{2}\) which contains all the product sets.

If \(E \subset S_{1} \times S_{2}\) and \(x \in S_{1}\), then \(E_{x} \subset S_{2}\) is called an \(x\)-slice of \(E\) where

\[ E_{x}: = \{y \in S_{2}; (x,y) \in E\}.\]

  • Proposition 6.2.1 If \(E \in \Sigma _{1} \otimes \Sigma _{2}\) then \(E_{x} \in \Sigma _{2}\) for all \(x \in S_{1}\).

  • Corollary 6.2.2 Let \(f: S_{1} \times S_{2} \rightarrow \R \) be measurable and fix \(x \in S_{1}\). Define \(f_{x}:S_{2} \rightarrow \R \) by \(f_{x}(y) = f(x,y)\) for all \(y \in S_{2}\). Then \(f_{x}\) is a measurable function.

Proof: For all \(a \in \R \), we need to show that \(f_{x}^{-1}((a, \infty )) \in \Sigma _{2}\). Define \(E = f^{-1}((a, \infty ))\). Since \(f\) is measurable, \(E \in \Sigma _{1} \otimes \Sigma _{2}\). By Proposition 6.2.1, \(E_{x} \in \Sigma _{2}\). But \(E_{x}= f_{x}^{-1}((a, \infty ))\), and so the result follows.   ∎

We can similarly define \(y\)-slices of sets in \(S_{1} \times S_{2}\) and show that \(f_{y}: S_{1} \rightarrow \R \) is measurable, for any \(y \in \R \), where \(f_{y}(x) = f(x,y)\) for all \(x \in S_{1}\).

We seek to define the product measure \(m_{1} \times m_{2}\) on \((S_{1} \times S_{2}, \Sigma _{1} \otimes \Sigma _{2})\). We need to make an assumption about the measures that we are using. Let \((S, \Sigma , m)\) be a measure space. We say that the measure \(m\) is \(\sigma \)-finite if there exists a sequence \((A_{n})\) of subsets of \(S\) with \(A_{n} \in \Sigma \) for all \(\nN \) such that \(S = \bigcup _{n=1}^{\infty }A_{n}\) and \(m(A_{n}) < \infty \) for all \(\nN \). Clearly any finite measure (and hence all probability measures) are \(\sigma \)-finite. It is easy to see that Lebesgue measure on \(\R \) is \(\sigma \)-finite. A measure space \((S, \Sigma , m)\) is said to be \(\sigma \)-finite, if \(m\) is a \(\sigma \)-finite measure.

From now on, let \((S_{1}, \Sigma _{1}, m_{1})\) and \((S_{2}, \Sigma _{2}, m_{2})\) be \(\sigma \)-finite measure spaces. Let \(E \in \Sigma _{1} \otimes \Sigma _{2}\) and define \(\phi _{E}: S_{1} \rightarrow \R \) by

\[ \phi _{E}(x) = m_{2}(E_{x}) ,\]

for all \(x \in S_{1}\). By using the Dynkin \(\pi -\lambda \) lemma, you can show that \(\phi _{E}\) is measurable. Then we define product measure of \(E\) by

\[ (m_{1} \times m_{2})(E) = \int _{S_{1}} \phi _{E}(x)dm_{1}(x).\]

Again using the Dynkin \(\pi -\lambda \) lemma, you can show that this definition is consistent, in that

\[ (m_{1} \times m_{2})(E) = \int _{S_{2}} \psi _{E}(y)dm_{2}(y),\]

where \(\psi _{E}: S_{2} \rightarrow \R \) is the measurable function defined by \(\psi _{E}(y) = m_{1}(E_{y})\) for all \(y \in S_{2}\).

In Problem 3 you can check that if \(E = A \times B\) is a product set, then

\[ (m_{1} \times m_{2})(A \times B) = m_{1}(A)m_{2}(B).\]

It can be shown that \({\cal B}(\R ^{2}) = {\cal B}(\R ) \otimes {\cal B}(\R )\) and Lebesgue measure on \(\R ^{2}\) is precisely \(\lambda \times \lambda \).

Copyright Nic Freeman, Sheffield University, last updated March 23, 2023

\(\newcommand{\footnotename}{footnote}\) \(\def \LWRfootnote {1}\) \(\newcommand {\footnote }[2][\LWRfootnote ]{{}^{\mathrm {#1}}}\) \(\newcommand {\footnotemark }[1][\LWRfootnote ]{{}^{\mathrm {#1}}}\) \(\let \LWRorighspace \hspace \) \(\renewcommand {\hspace }{\ifstar \LWRorighspace \LWRorighspace }\) \(\newcommand {\mathnormal }[1]{{#1}}\) \(\newcommand \ensuremath [1]{#1}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRframebox }[2][]{\fbox {#2}} \newcommand {\framebox }[1][]{\LWRframebox } \) \(\newcommand {\setlength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtolength }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\setcounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\addtocounter }[2]{}\) \(\newcommand {\arabic }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\number }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\noalign }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\newcommand {\cline }[1]{}\) \(\newcommand {\directlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\luatexdirectlua }[1]{\text {(directlua)}}\) \(\newcommand {\protect }{}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbnumber #1 {}\) \(\def \LWRabsorbquotenumber "#1 {}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorboption }[1][]{}\) \(\newcommand {\LWRabsorbtwooptions }[1][]{\LWRabsorboption }\) \(\def \mathchar {\ifnextchar "\LWRabsorbquotenumber \LWRabsorbnumber }\) \(\def \mathcode #1={\mathchar }\) \(\let \delcode \mathcode \) \(\let \delimiter \mathchar \) \(\def \oe {\unicode {x0153}}\) \(\def \OE {\unicode {x0152}}\) \(\def \ae {\unicode {x00E6}}\) \(\def \AE {\unicode {x00C6}}\) \(\def \aa {\unicode {x00E5}}\) \(\def \AA {\unicode {x00C5}}\) \(\def \o {\unicode {x00F8}}\) \(\def \O {\unicode {x00D8}}\) \(\def \l {\unicode {x0142}}\) \(\def \L {\unicode {x0141}}\) }[1]{\text {#1}\notag \\}\) \(\let \Hat \hat \) \(\let \Check \check \) \(\let \Tilde \tilde \) \(\let \Acute \acute \) \(\let \Grave \grave \) \(\let \Dot \dot \) \(\let \Ddot \ddot \) \(\let \Breve )}\) \(\newcommand {\F }{{\cal F}}\) \(\newcommand {\ds }{\displaystyle }\) \(\newcommand {\st }{\stackrel {d}{=}}\) \(\newcommand {\uc }{\stackrel {uc}{\rightarrow }}\) \(\newcommand {\la }{\langle }\) \(\newcommand {\ra }{\rangle }\) \(\newcommand {\li }{\liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\ls }{\limsup _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\newcommand {\limn }{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty }}\) \(\def \to {\rightarrow }\) \(\def \iff {\Leftrightarrow }\) \(\def \sw {\subseteq }\) \(\def \mc {\mathcal }\) \(\def \mb {\mathbb }\) \(\def \sc {\setminus }\) \(\def \v {\textbf }\) \(\def \E {\mb {E}}\) \(\def \P {\mb {P}}\) \(\def \R {\mb {R}}\) \(\def \C {\mb {C}}\) \(\def \N {\mb {N}}\) \(\def \Q {\mb {Q}}\) \(\def \Z {\mb {Z}}\) \(\def \B {\mb {B}}\) \(\def \~{\sim }\) \(\def \-{\,;\,}\) \(\def \qed {$\blacksquare $}\) \(\def \1{\unicode {x1D7D9}}\) \(\def \cadlag {c\`{a}dl\`{a}g}\) \(\def \p {\partial }\) \(\def \l {\left }\) \(\def \r {\right }\) \(\def \Om {\Omega }\) \(\def \om {\omega }\)

6.3 Fubini’s Theorem \((\Delta )\)

We give two versions of this important result - one for general non-negative measurable functions and the other for integrable functions.

  • Theorem 6.3.1 (Fubini’s Theorem 1) Let \(f: S_{1} \times S_{2} \rightarrow \R \) be a non-negative measurable function. Then the mappings

    \[ x \rightarrow \int _{S_{2}}f(x, y)dm_{2}(y),\]

    \[ \mbox {and}~~ y \rightarrow \int _{S_{1}}f(x, y)dm_{1}(x),\]

    are both measurable. Furthermore

    \(\seteqnumber{0}{6.}{0}\)

    \begin{eqnarray} \label {Fub} \int _{S_{1} \times S_{2}}f d(m_{1} \times m_{2}) & = \int _{S_{1}} \left (\int _{S_{2}}f(x, y)dm_{2}(y)\right )dm_{1}(x) \nonumber \\ & = \int _{S_{2}} \left (\int _{S_{1}}f(x, y)dm_{1}(x)\right )dm_{2}(y). \end{eqnarray}

The proof works by first establishing the result for indicator functions, and then extending by linearity to simple functions. The next step is to take an arbitrary non-negative measurable function, approximate it by simple functions as in Theorem 2.4.1 and use the monotone convergence theorem. Note that all three integrals in (6.1) may be infinite. The next result is more useful for applications.

  • Theorem 6.3.2 (Fubini’s Theorem 2) Let \(f: S_{1} \times S_{2} \rightarrow \R \) be an integrable function. Then the mappings

    \[ x \rightarrow \int _{S_{2}}f(x, y)dm_{2}(y),\]

    \[ \mbox {and}~~ y \rightarrow \int _{S_{1}}f(x, y)dm_{1}(x),\]

    are both equal (a.e.) to integrable functions. Furthermore

    \(\seteqnumber{0}{6.}{1}\)

    \begin{eqnarray} \label {Fub1} \int _{S_{1} \times S_{2}}f d(m_{1} \times m_{2}) & = \int _{S_{1}} \left (\int _{S_{2}}f(x, y)dm_{2}(y)\right )dm_{1}(x) \nonumber \\ & = \int _{S_{2}} \left (\int _{S_{1}}f(x, y)dm_{1}(x)\right )dm_{2}(y). \end{eqnarray}

The proof works by writing \(f = f_{+} - f_{-}\) and applying Theorem 6.3.1 to \(f_{-}\) and \(f_{+}\) separately.

All of the results of this chapter extend in a straightforward way to products of finitely many measure spaces.

Copyright Nic Freeman, Sheffield University, last updated March 23, 2023
